metadata.title: Dysphagia  Progressive Supranuclear Palsy
anatomical location body part affected: Mouth, oropharynx, pharynx, esophagus, and respiratory systems.(1) Brain structures involved include globus pallidus, subthalamus, dentate nucleus, substantia nigra, mesencephalic tectum, and periaqueductal grey matter(2)
description: Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is a progressive extrapyramidal disease that causes severe problems with gait and balance.(3) Other symptoms include difficulty focusing and aiming the eyes, diplopia, eyelid apraxia, stiffness, awkward movements, falling, incontinence, irritability, anxiety, loss of interest in formerly pleasurable activities (anhedonia), forgetfulness, frontal-lobe  type dementia, pseudobulbar affect (laughing or crying for no reason), and speech and swallowing difficulties(2,3)

ICD-9 codes.333.0: other degenerative diseases of the basal ganglia

ICD-10 codes.G23.1: progressive supranuclear ophthalmoplegia [Steele-Richardson-Olszewski] _ (ICD codes are provided for the readers’ reference, not for billing purposes)

Swallowing G-code set.G8996: Swallowing functional limitation, current status at time of initial therapy treatment/episode outset and reporting intervals
Swallowing G-code set.G8997: Swallowing functional limitation, projected goal status, at initial therapy treatment/outset and at discharge from therapy
Swallowing G-code set.G8998: Swallowing functional limitation, discharge status, at discharge from therapy/end of reporting on limitation

reimbursement: Reimbursement for procedure will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific issues or information regarding reimbursement have been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Dysphagia refers to an inability to move food and liquids efficiently during the oral, pharyngeal, or esophageal phase of swallowing.(4) The oral phase includes sucking and chewing food and moving the food or liquid into the throat. The pharyngeal phase is the initiation of the swallowing reflex, when the food or liquid is squeezed down the throat and the airway is closed off to prevent aspiration (food or liquid entering the airway) or choking. In the esophageal phase, the openings at the top and bottom of the esophagus move the food or liquid to the stomach by relaxing and tightening.(5) Symptoms of dysphagia in patients with PSP have been noted in all phases of swallowing: coughing, choking, food sticking at the base of the tongue, pocketing of food in the cheeks, aspiration, and abnormalities in esophageal motility.(6) Aspiration pneumonia has been cited as a common cause of death in patients with PSP(6,7)

Oral phase deficits include: –Uncoordinated lingual movements(8) –Absent velar retraction or elevation(8) –Impaired posterior lingual displacement(8) –Ineffectual mastication and tongue-assisted  mastication(8) –Uncoordinated lingual movements(8)  –Excessive leakage of oral bolus(8) –Overstuffing the mouth(8)
Pharyngeal phase deficits include: –Pooling in valleculae and pyriform sinuses(8) –Abnormal epiglottic positioning(8)
Esophageal phase deficits include: –Hiatal hernias(8) –Slowed or absent lower esophageal closure(8) –Gastroesophageal reflux(8) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: During a swallowing evaluation, it is of utmost importance to be aware of a patient’s pain level, fatigue level, and frustration level. The time of day and the number of previous evaluations can affect the patient’s alertness and performance. Swallowing assessments should be scheduled at a time of day when the patient is less fatigued and should not occur following other assessments
It is recommended that the caregiver/family be involved in all assessment procedures

pathogenesis: The prevalence of PSP has been reported as 5 cases (from an age-adjusted  sample) per 100,000 persons.(9) Pathologically,the disorder is characterized by neuronal loss, granulovacuolar degeneration and gliosis (proliferation of glial cells),and neurofibrillary tangles in the basal ganglia, brainstem, and cerebellar nuclei.(9) Onset of PSP is usually after the ageof 50 with symptoms of bradykinesia (slowed ability to initiate and complete movements), gait disturbance, rigidity,impaired control of vertical eye movements, dysphagia, and dysarthria.(8) Dementia is present in most patients, as are otherneuropsychologic abnormalities, including personality changes, depression, and emotional lability(8)
risk factors for psp: Older age (peak onset has been reported as 63 years of age; there are no cases reported below age 40)(2)
Family history of PSP is a possible risk factor(2)

overall contraindications precautions: Speech-language  pathologists (SLPs) are required to have graduate, postgraduate, or continuing education training specifically in dysphagia assessment and treatment(10)
To perform videofluoroscopic swallowing studies (VFSSs), SLPs must have established competencies in the use and storage of barium used in VFSSs(11)

Patients with dysphagia are at risk for aspiration and/or penetration of oral intake. Ensure that the patient and family/ caregivers are aware of potential aspiration risks and educated about prevention strategies when appropriate
The patient’s family/caregivers should be involved in assessment and treatment procedures
A patient’s culture and native language should be considered to determine the appropriateness of examination questions and materials
It is important to consider eating habits, food preferences, and cultural influences on eating to maximize nutritional intake

Patients who have PSP might also have communication and cognitive deficits that might interfere with their ability to follow assessment instructions and treatment protocol. (For detailed information on assessment and treatment of dementia, see Clinical Review…Dementia, Frontotemporal ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708948)

The time of day and the number of previous evaluations can affect the patient’s alertness and performance. Swallowing assessments should be scheduled at a time of day when the patient is less fatigued and should not occur following other assessments

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document the onset of symptoms (e.g., date of onset of falls) and when the PSP was diagnosed

course of treatment.medical management: There is no cure for PSP, but some treatments help to improve symptoms of the disorder.(12) InThese medications increase the levels of dopamine (which is involved in smooth, controlled muscle movements) and might improve symptoms in the short term (for ~ 23 years)(12) Authors of a case study reported on 3 patients with dysphagia related to PSP who were treated with levodopa. Authors reported clinical signs of improvement in swallowing with all 3 patients and recommended larger studies to determine the exact effects of levodopa on dysphagia in patients with PSP(41)Injections of botulinum toxin might alleviate symptoms of eyelid spasms(12)Mobility and balance might be improved by therapy and adaptive devices(12)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they being taken? Ask a pharmacist or physician about the side effects of these medications. PSP is not responsive to the same types of medications that are recommended for improving motor function and swallowing in Parkinson disease(6)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for dysphagia associated with PSP include the following:
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether the patient has had occupational, physical, or speech therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Does the patient exhibit dementia? Does the patient have diplopia or other vision difficulties (e.g., difficulty focusing, apraxia of the eyelid opening)?(9) Does the patient show a lack of interest in food? -With certain textures of foods or liquids? -In different environments? -As meal progresses? -During certain times of day? -If fatigued? -With environmental distractions?
history of present illness.body chart: Review body chart to determine extent of muscle weakness
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Symptoms of dysphagia in patients with PSP have been noted in all phases of the swallow and are similar to those found in patients with Parkinson disease. See Presenting signs and symptoms , above
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 0-10 scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); document any history of coughing while eating. Document any fatigue while eating
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient might be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., coughing, chest congestion, difficulty with oral hygiene, dehydration, weakness, constipation)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document any history of respiratory difficultiesDocument psychosocial status; dementia is present in most patients, as are other neuropsychologic abnormalities, including personality changes, depression, apathy, and emotional lability.(8,9) Patients with PSP might benefit from a referral to a mental health professionalDocument hearing ability, including use of hearing aids Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe ________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Document any previous history of swallowing difficulties, respiratory difficulties, communication difficulties, or cognitive deficits
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Refer to medical charts and ask the patient or patient’s family about other problems, including depression, hearing loss, vision problems, heart problems, communication difficulties, and memory loss
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient about other symptoms he or she is experiencing (e.g., excessive throat clearing, coughing while eating)

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient work? Does the patient participate in hobbies that might lead to fatigue? Does the patient engage in social mealtimes? Does the patient avoid eating situations that might be difficult, such as eating in a restaurant or with friends?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document if the patient uses any adaptive equipment for mobility or to communicate (e.g., pen/paper, communication board). Does the patient self-feed? Is the patient limited to eating foods of only certain textures?
social and occupational history.living environment: Document with whom the patient lives (e.g., caregivers, family members)

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Does the patient use any adaptive devices for mobility, communication, or eating (e.g., adaptive spoons, cups)?
relevant tests and measures.posture: Note any posture abnormalities that might interfere with swallowing (e.g., head tilt, unilateral weakness) Quality of lifeAn outcome measure that includes patient self-ratings  of quality of life due to swallowing and eating ability(15)Document if the patient is able to eat independently
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Vision and hearing screening should be performed to determine any barriers to communication and ability to follow treatment protocol. Ideally, referral to an audiologist to check for impacted cerumen should be made prior to hearing screening. If the patient has hearing aids, they should be checked to be sure they are in working order. Patients with PSP have visual problems such as diplopia, difficulty focusing, and apraxia of the eyelid opening.(9) These symptoms might hinder dysphagia treatment by making it difficult for the patient to perceive food on the plate
relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: It is important to screen communication functioning before a swallow evaluation to determine the patient’s ability to follow directions. Many patients who have PSP have cognitive-linguistic  deficits as well as dysarthria. Palilalia, or frequent repeating of one’s own words, has also been reported in patients with PSP.(9) (For detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysarthria, please see Clinical Review…T708884)
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Most patients with later stage PSP have dementia. (For detailed information on assessment and treatment of dementia, see Clinical Review…Dementia, Frontotemporal , referenced above.) If applicable, refer to psychological and cognitive evaluations to assist in informing course of treatment and providing a prognosis for therapy. A lack of awareness of dysphagic symptoms has been associated with more medical complications as compared to patients who have an awareness of dysphagic symptoms. In addition, patients who are unaware of the swallowing problem are less likely to modify their swallowing behavior(13)
relevant tests and measures.swallow examination: The purpose of a swallow examination is to determine if the patient has dysphagia, to determine which function is disordered, and to establish any compensatory strategies (change in swallowing manner or food(10)A BSE is usually the first part of a comprehensive swallowing examination or is used as an initial screening to determine the need for further evaluation.(10) Historically, the lack of a gag reflex function was used as a measure of dysphagia, but this has been demonstrated as unreliable as the sole indicator of swallowing function.(10) The featuresa wet voice, weak voluntary cough, cough on swallowing, and delayed or prolonged swallow.(16) However, BSEs are poor at detecting silent aspiration (aspiration of food or liquid into the lungs without overt signs) and in determining the physiologic reason for a cough or a voice quality change. Due to its limitations, a BSE should be used as a complement to other instrumental measures rather than in isolation.(16) If oral intake is considered relatively safe, the patient might be observed swallowing different consistencies of food during the BSE.(14) Cervical auscultation (the use of a stethoscope to assess swallow sounds and airway sounds) and pulse oximetry (oxygen saturation is measured before, during, and after swallowing; decreased saturation during and after swallowing is reported to be associated with aspiration)can be used during trial swallows to better detect penetration/aspiration atCervicalT709100. For adults, the BSE might include the following -A comprehensive case history and review of medical records(10) -Assessment of oral structures and motor function. Note the appearance of the oral mucosa (e.g., any inflammation or infection that might affect the oral stage of swallowing) and any pooling of saliva in the oral cavity. An inability to swallow might cause the saliva to pool in the mouth. Evaluate dentition in terms of the presence or absence of dental prostheses, the number and appearance of teeth, and general dental care.(10) Examine the facial, labial, and lingual range of motion, speed, and strength. Examine velar elevation -Assessment of speech and vocal quality(10) -Assessment of feeding and mealtime techniques used by patient and caregivers.(10) When possible, conduct the BSE during a regular meal to observe the patient’s skills in coordinating respiration and swallowing in a natural environment.(10) Assess patient’s ability to achieve labial seal and contain bolus. Examine retrieval of different food consistencies from a spoon, cup, and straw -Assess the pharyngeal phase by using palpation. To assess tongue-based function, hyoid motion, and laryngeal motion during a swallow, place one finger under the patient’s chin at the base of the tongue, the next finger on the hyoid bone, the next finger above the larynx, and the next finger below the larynx.(17) As the patient swallows, examine for the presence and extent of laryngeal elevation -Observe the effects of alterations in posture or other compensatory techniques to improve swallow(10) -Evaluate the patient’s ability to comprehend instructions and use compensatory strategies(18)Several screening protocols have been published to assist the clinician during the BSE -Burke Dysphagia Screening Test (BDST) -Standardized Swallowing Assessment (SSA) -Bedside Swallowing Assessment (BSA) –Assessment scales/checklistsLip, cheek, tongue, and jaw movement are rated during a typical meal. This scale can be used with patients from 1 year of age through adulthood(20)A statistically based protocol for patients who are dependent feeders. Scaled ratings are made for posture, tone, reflexes, general motor control, orofacial structures, orofacial sensory input, orofacial motor control, ventilation, and functional feeding assessment(21)Ratings of lip, jaw, and tongue movement during ingestion of liquids and solid foods. Assessment of sipping from a cup, coughing, gagging, and hypersensitivity associated with feeding and swallowing. A checklist allows for indication of abnormal oral structures, oral reflexes, positioning, diet, utensils and feeding(22)Standardized screening survey that can be used with children from 2 years of age to adults. Assesses body mass index, restrictions in food textures and viscosity, dependence in feeding, and need for special  utensils or positioning. Provides information on the severity of the swallowing disorder and can be used as an outcome measure(23)In-depth  Bedside SwallowT709037VFSS is performed in collaboration with a physician (radiologist or physiatrist) and an SLP or occupational therapist and is used primarily as a diagnostic procedure for dysphagia.(10) Most clinical practices follow the protocol originally described by Logemann.(24) The patient eats and drinks a variety of liquids and solids mixed with barium while images are recorded with videofluorography. All patients should be examined in the lateral and frontal positions to gain information on movements of the swallow and symmetry of bolus flow and pharyngeal wall contraction. The SLP examines for the presence of aspiration and the effectiveness of modifying different food consistencies or of modifying posture.(10) In contrast to the BSE, VFSS provides critical information on the pharyngeal and esophageal phases of the swallow.(14) Due to the levels of radiation involved, this procedure is not suitable to use frequently to monitor changes.(16) Given the unnatural surroundings, swallowing function observed during a VFSS is not necessarily identical to the swallowing function displayed at mealtimes.(19) Other variables that might influence swallowing function include anxiety, fatigue, and medications.(25)(18,25) -Lip closure (ability to contain a liquid bolus) -Lingual elevation (the back of the tongue is slightly elevated) -Tongue-to-palatal  seal -Bolus preparation/mastication -Bolus transport/movement of the tongue (movement of the bolus to the back of the oral cavity) -Initiation of the pharyngeal swallow (swallow should be initiated when the bolus reaches the region of the posterior oral cavity) -Soft palate elevation and retraction -Laryngeal elevation -Anterior hyoid excursion -Laryngeal closure -Pharyngeal contraction -Pharyngoesophageal segment opening -Tongue base retraction -Epiglottic inversion -Esophageal clearanceModified Barium SwallowT709046FEES is performed to evaluate the anatomy and physiology of the pharynx and the larynx, pharyngeal swallow function, and the patient’s ability to manage secretions as well as the ability to swallow foods and liquids.(10) In addition, it can be used to explore a variety of diagnostic interventions such as varying bolus consistency, varying posture, or making use of visual feedback for reinforcement.(26) After the insertion of the endoscope, the patient can self-feed  during the evaluation. Food must be light in color to enhance visibility (e.g., milk, puddings, yogurt, bread). FEES is preferred over VFSS when patients have safety issues related to radiation exposure or need retesting. In addition, FEES is typically less taxing than VFSS for patients who are weak and bedridden.(26) The American Speech-Language-Hearing  Association (ASHA) has published several online documents relevant to the technical aspects of FEES and the qualifications required to perform FEES(27) -For detailed information on endoscopic assessment of swallowing, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic –Other instrumental procedures include ultrasonography to observe movement of the structures used for swallowing and surface electromyography to record the electrical activity of the swallowing muscles; however, these procedures are used primarily in research at this time.(10) For detailed information on assessment of swallowing with electromyography,Electromyography ; CINAHL Topic ID Number auscultation by a physical therapist has also been used as an adjunct to a bedside assessment(28)

other: Patients with PSP syndrome are at risk for falls due to deficits in mobility and balance; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall prevention strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall prevention strategies

Patients with dysphagia are at risk for aspiration and penetration of oral intake. Ensure that the patient and family/ caregivers are aware of potential aspiration risks and are educated about prevention strategies when appropriate

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Dysphagia diagnosis and management is based upon the results of a comprehensive assessment that is performed by an SLP in collaboration with a transdisciplinary team that might include a dietitian, occupational therapist, physical therapist, respiratory therapist, otolaryngologist, radiologist, social worker, and neurologist.(29) Each discipline will provide specific input and expertise on the patient’s swallowing problems and the treatment plan. The primary concern is to maintain and maximize the patient’s health status.(10) After the evaluation, a decision must be made about the patient’s ability to ingest food and water orally based upon the nature of the disorder and the patient’s ability to make adjustments
assessment plan of care.rule out: The physician must rule out conditions with similar symptoms, such as Parkinson disease(8)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Refer to an occupational therapist, physical therapist, nutritionist, respiratory therapist, social worker, neurologist, otolaryngologist, radiologist, or gastroenterologist as necessary. Patient and caregiver depression and frustration might result from altered social habits around eating (e.g., cessation of eating out, inviting friends to meals, longer duration of mealtimes, increased dependency on caregiver). Refer to support groups or counseling when signs of depression are present(30)
treatment summary: Diet modification:  Changing the food and/or liquid consistency of a patient’s diet might assist in improving the safety and efficiency of the swallow as well as reduce fatigue associated with eating. For example, if a patient reports fatigue while chewing, the diet can be changed to mechanical soft texture.(17) If the patient reports aspiration of liquids or difficulty containing the liquid in the oral cavity, the clinician might investigate the used of thickened liquids; however, it cannot be assumed that all patients benefit from thickened liquids.(32) Clinicians should explore all possible intervention options  before recommending thickened liquids, and also ensure (by observing modifications during VFSS), rather than assume, that aspiration is not occurring with thickened liquids(33) –For detailed information on diet modifications for dysphagia treatment, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Swallowing Therapy – Compensatory ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709081

Postural therapy:  Several postures have been examined to assist in changing the direction of the flow of foods and liquids for patients with dysphagia, including the chin tuck, head back, head rotation, and head tilt. Patients with PSP and dementia might need auditory or visual cues to remember to use postural strategies during mealtimes: –Chin tuck (chin down): The chin down posture serves to narrow the distance between the tongue base and pharyngeal wall and is often effective for patients with tongue-base  disorders. This posture widens the valleculae so that it can more easily capture the bolus during a delay in the pharyngeal swallow and prevent aspiration before swallowing(32) –Head back (chin elevated): This posture is beneficial for patients who have difficulty moving the tongue or generating adequate lingual pressures to move the bolus from the mouth to the pharynx. For additional protection of the airway, patients can hold their breath before lifting the chin (supraglottic swallow)(32) –Head rotation: This position is useful when there is unilateral laryngeal paralysis or pharyngeal wall paresis. The head should be rotated to the side of the damage so that the pharynx is closed on the weak side and the bolus is directed towards the stronger side(32) –Head tilt: Tilting the head towards the stronger side can also direct the bolus down the stronger side. This might be useful for patients who have neurologic damage on one side of their mouth and pharynx(32) –For detailed information on postural changes as dysphagia treatment, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Swallowing Therapy – Compensatory , referenced above

Sensory stimuli:  Changing the taste, volume, temperature, or carbonation of the food or liquid has been used as a way to heighten sensation and assist with delayed oral onset and/or delayed pharyngeal swallow.(17) There is no research on the use of sensory stimuli in patients with PSP, and research is needed to determine its effects(32) –For detailed information on changes to sensory aspects of the bolus for dysphagia treatment, see Clinical Review… Dysphagia: Swallowing Therapy –Compensatory , referenced above

Swallow maneuvers (voluntary changes in the swallow):  Swallow maneuvers include the supraglottic swallow, the super-supraglottic  swallow, the effortful swallow, and the Mendelsohn maneuver. Research has documented specific changes in the oropharyngeal swallow due to these maneuvers for some patients; however, further research is needed to determine the amount of time that these maneuvers should be used. Patients might not be able to perform maneuvers if they are unable to follow instructions or remember to use the maneuver during each swallow. In addition, these strategies might be contraindicated if the patient fatigues easily –Supraglottic swallow: Breath is held before, during, and after the swallow so that the true vocal folds are closed.(32) This technique might be contraindicated for patients with PSP who have impaired respiratory function(33) –Super-supraglottic  swallow: Breath is held while the patient also swallows with extra effort.(32) This technique might be contraindicated for patients with PSP who have impaired respiratory function(33) –Effortful swallow: Patient contracts the muscles involved in swallowing with great effort(32) –Mendelsohn maneuver: The Mendelsohn maneuver is designed to increase the movement of the larynx and hyoid during the pharyngeal swallow. The patient holds the larynx up by using the muscles of the neck or with the hand –For detailed information on maneuvers in dysphagia treatment, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Swallowing Therapy – Swallow Maneuvers – an Overview ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709042 and the series of Clinical Reviews on each specific type of maneuver

Adaptive equipment : Adaptive spoons, cups, and straws might be used to assist with the oral stage of the swallow. For example, if the patient has difficulty achieving a labial seal and cannot drink from a straw, a nonspill cup with a large handle might be useful as a facilitative aid. If anterior leakage continues, spoons can be used to place the liquid more posterior in the mouth.(17) A nonskid mat can stabilize objects on the table(17)

Feeding tubes/enteral feeding:  Patients with severe forms of dysphagia might be unable to take adequate nutrition and hydration by mouth and might require a percutaneous endoscopic gastronomy tube (PEG) or a radiologically inserted gastronomy tube.(34) Tube feeding is indicated in patients who cannot eat or drink enough to maintain sufficient weight and hydration

Medication: In a pilot study conducted in the United States, researchers investigated the use of physostigmine, a centrally active cholinesterase inhibitor, on swallowing function of patients with PSP. The researchers who conducted the controlled, double-blind  crossover trial did not find any significant improvement in oral motor function or swallow duration(7) . The following recommendations might assist the patient in optimizing nutritional intake during meals:(18) 1.Caregivers should be instructed to assist the patient in maintaining good oral hygiene(18) 2.The patient should have a consistent environment and seat in the dining area for mealtimes 3.The patient might benefit from several small meals a day (e.g., 6 meals) rather than three large meals. reduced aspiration risk: Presence of aspiration (measured by presence of fevers, x-rays)(17)
improved nutrition and hydration: Measures of liquid intake and skin turgor(17)
improved quality of life: SWAL-QOL:  An outcome measure that includes patient self-ratings  of quality of life due to swallowing and eatingability(15)

General quality of life measures were trialed in a study involving patients with PSP and their caregivers (N = 27). Thefollowing were found to be useful in assessment of these patients:–PDQ-39:  A quality of life measure to assess patients with Parkinson disease. It includes 39 questions with answer options(never, occasionally, sometimes, often, and always) and yields 8 subscores (mobility, activities of daily living, emotionalwell-being,  stigma, social support, cognition, communication, and bodily discomfort) as well as a total summary score(37)–EQ-5D:  A generic quality of life measure that has been validated in patients with Parkinson disease. It contains 5questions on Mobility, Self-Care,  Usual Activities, Pain/Discomfort, and Anxiety/Depression with three possible answers(no problem, some problem, and extreme problem)(38)

maintenance or prevention: Patient and caregiver education about dysphagia, including the importance of nutrition and hydration, should be initiated before symptoms first appear(39)
The patient’s swallowing ability should be regularly monitored because PSP is a progressive disorder
patient education: The SLP is responsible for educating the family and patient care staff about the needs of the patient regarding swallow safety. In addition, the caregivers should be educated and counseled about symptoms of frontal lobe dysfunction such as depression, apathy, loss of interest in pleasurable activities, and personality changes
